summary: Frank Friberg was the COS (Chief of Station) in Helsinki, as indicated in the documents. His significance arises from his involvement in discussions and inquiries related to Lee Harvey Oswald's stay in Helsinki in October 1959. The documents suggest that Friberg was questioned about Oswald's contact with the Soviet Consulate during his time in Finland, specifically in relation to the Warren Commission's investigation. The memos indicate that Friberg provided information and insights regarding the timeline of Oswald's activities in Helsinki. He had recently returned from his post as COS Helsinki when the memo was written.
significance: Frank Friberg's significance lies in his role as the COS Helsinki during Lee Harvey Oswald's visit, making him a key source of information regarding Oswald's activities and contacts in Finland. His testimony and insights were relevant to the Warren Commission's investigation into Oswald's movements and potential connections.
